title: 110_hr3648
content: The "Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007" excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Special rules are established for this type of indebtedness. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has special rules for qualified principal residence indebtedness. The exclusion from gross income reduces the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. Qualified principal residence indebtedness is defined as acquisition indebtedness up to $2,000,000. The exclusion from gross income for qualified principal residence indebtedness under section 163(h)(3)(B) applies up to $2,000,000 ($1,000,000 for principal residence). There is an exception for loan discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition, and an ordering rule for discharged loans. The exclusion for qualified principal residence indebtedness applies up to $2,000,000 ($1,000,000 for principal residence) with exceptions for loan discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition and an ordering rule for discharged loans. The term 'principal residence' has the same meaning as in section 121. Coordination amendments are made to section 108(a)(2) and 108(a) of the Code regarding the principal residence exclusion taking precedence over the insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise by the taxpayer. The amendments made by this section regarding discharges of indebtedness shall apply to events occurring on or after January 1, 2007, unless the taxpayer elects otherwise. SEC. 3. Extension of treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. SEC. 4. Alternative tests for qualifying as cooperative housing corporation. The amendment to section 216(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines a cooperative housing corporation meeting specific requirements related to gross income and property usage. The amendment to section 216(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 specifies that a cooperative housing corporation must meet certain criteria regarding property usage and expenditures. The amendment will be effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section, SEC. 139B, which excludes benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization member, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and payments. Deductions and expenses related to services as a member are subject to specific rules. The curr_chunk discusses how expenses related to services as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization are taken into account for tax purposes only if they exceed any qualified payment excluded from gross income. Definitions for "qualified state and local tax benefit" and "qualified payment" are provided. The curr_chunk explains that a "qualified payment" refers to any payment provided by a State or political division for services as a member of a volunteer emergency response organization, with a maximum limit of $30 per month per taxpayer. The term 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' refers to a volunteer organization providing firefighting or emergency medical services, required by a State or political subdivision to do so. The section applies to qualified volunteer emergency response organizations providing firefighting or emergency medical services as required by a State or political subdivision, and it terminates for taxable years after December 31, 2010. The amendments apply to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The clarification of student housing eligible for low-income housing credit is also addressed in the section. The amendment to section 42(i)(3)(D)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 pertains to single parents and their children who are not dependents of another individual, except for a parent of such children. The amendment in section 42(i)(3)(D)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applies to housing credit amounts allocated and buildings placed in service before or after the enactment date of the Act. Additionally, the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion is extended to certain post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include a special rule for certain sales by surviving spouses within 2 years of their spouse's death, allowing for a higher capital gains exclusion limit of $500,000 instead of $250,000. This amendment applies to sales or exchanges of property meeting specific requirements. The special rule for certain sales by surviving spouses within 2 years of their spouse's death allows for a higher capital gains exclusion limit of $500,000 instead of $250,000. This amendment applies to sales or exchanges after December 31, 2007. SEC. 8. Modification of penalty for failure to file partnership returns; limitation on disclosure. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is raised from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to certain individuals is also amended. The amendment limits disclosure of taxpayer identity information in partnership, S corporation, trust, or estate returns. The amendment restricts the disclosure of taxpayer identity information in certain types of returns. The effective date for this change is the date of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns. Penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 includes penalties for late filing or incomplete information, with a maximum penalty of 12 months unless reasonable cause is shown. Penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 can result in a penalty assessed against the S corporation. The penalty amount is calculated at $85 per month multiplied by the number of shareholders in the S corporation during the taxable year. Deficiency procedures do not apply to this penalty. Penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns under section 6037 can result in a penalty assessed against the S corporation. Deficiency procedures do not apply to this penalty. The amendments under Sec. 6699 apply to S corporation returns filed after the enactment date. Modification of corporate estimated tax installment percentages is increased by 1.50 points.
